title: Country radio host Bob Kingsley dies at the age of 80
text:
Country music radio host Bob Kingsley died on Thursday at home in Weatherford, Texas at the age of 80.

This news comes just one week after the National Radio Hall of Fame broadcaster revealed he was battling bladder cancer and getting treatment.

The star had also said at the time that he was retiring from his syndicated radio show, Bob Kingsley's Country Top 40.

Sad loss: Country music radio host Bob Kingsley died on Thursday at home in Weatherford, Texas at the age of 80. Seen in 2017 in Nashville

'While there is no doubt that the immediate road ahead will push me and challenge my resolve, I want you to know I am blessed to be working with the very best in the medical profession, and they have a plan to deal with this awful disease,' he wrote on social media earlier this month.

'I have no intention of stopping anytime soon, but for a moment, I need to ask for your patience as I step away from the mic and focus on my treatment.'

Bob was well liked in the country music world and called Dolly Parton, Kenny Rogers, Keith Urban, Kenny Chesney, Blake Shelton, and Garth Brooks friends.

He had many country friends: With Thomas Rhett during Life Changes Lunch & Listen Q & A on Bob Kingsley Country Top 40 in 2017

Another longtime friend: Here he is posed with Bobby Bones (L) at the 11th Annual ACM Honors at the Ryman Auditorium in 2017

He came to fame in 1978 when he became the host of American Country Countdown, a job he held down until 2006.

On the side, Bob hosted album release specials for stars such as Taylor Swift and Carrie Underwood.

In 2016 he entered the National Radio Hall of Fame.

He is as the inaugural winner of the Bob Kingsley Living Legend Award. It is presented annually at the Grand Ole Opry House.

Bob was called 'the most recognized voice in the history of country music' by fellow syndicated-radio host Blair Garner.

Touching: Big D and Bubba added: 'Brokenhearted to hear of this radio legend's passing. Bob Kingsley was someone to look up to'

More love: Spencer Graves added, 'In radio, there are icons and today, we lost one'

His #1 fan: 'I listened to Bob Kingsley every Sunday. As a child and as a college kid driving from Knoxville to Johnson city. I had heroes in country music and Bob Kingsley brought those heroes closer to me,' Chesney told People. Seen in 2016

He is survived by his wife Nan Kingsley. The two were married for 30 years.

A 'celebration of life' is scheduled for November 14 at the CMA Theater at the Country Music Hall of Fame and Museum in Nashville

Tributes quickly flooded in.

'I listened to Bob Kingsley every Sunday. As a child and as a college kid driving from Knoxville to Johnson city. I had heroes in country music and Bob Kingsley brought those heroes closer to me,' Chesney told People.

With his love: Bob is seen far right and his wife Nan is center. They are posing with Country AirCheck's Lon Helton at the CMHOF Outlaws and Armadillos VIP Opening Reception in Nashville in 2018

'He made them real, made them human, and later when my career took off…. validated my own dream when he would talk about my songs and my journey.

'He was a friend. Not just an associate within the business but a true friend,' Chesney added. 'He was also a true friend of the genre of country music and it will never be the same without his voice. I'm going to miss him.'

Bobby Bones tweeted, 'Rest In Peace to Bob Kingsley. I spent many weekends as a kid listening to his countdown. And spent many occasions as I got older telling him how much I admired him. This picture is just one of those occasions. Rest easy friend.'

Big D and Bubba added: 'Brokenhearted to hear of this radio legend's passing. Bob Kingsley was someone to look up to. A man to learn from, a host we respected. He was someone listen to as well as someone to talk to. We are incredibly grateful that we have been blessed to have called Bob a friend.'
description: This news comes just one week after the National Radio Hall of Fame broadcaster revealed he was battling bladder cancer and getting treatment.
